title: Bally Sports Sun
text:
Bally Sports Sun is an American <a href="regional%20sports%20network">regional sports network</a> owned by <a href="Diamond%20Sports%20Group">Diamond Sports Group</a>, a joint venture between <a href="Sinclair%20Broadcast%20Group">Sinclair Broadcast Group</a> and <a href="Entertainment%20Studios">Entertainment Studios</a>, and operates as an affiliate of <a href="Bally%20Sports">Bally Sports</a>. The channel broadcasts local coverage of professional, collegiate and sporting events in the state of <a href="Florida">Florida</a>, with a focus on professional sports teams based in <a href="Miami">Miami</a>, <a href="Tampa%2C%20Florida">Tampa</a> and <a href="Orlando%2C%20Florida">Orlando</a>. Bally Sports Sun and sister regional sports network <a href="Bally%20Sports%20Florida">Bally Sports Florida</a> are headquartered in Fort Lauderdale, Florida with studios located in <a href="Tampa%2C%20Florida">Tampa</a>.
Bally Sports Sun is available on <a href="cable%20television">cable</a> providers throughout Florida; it is also available nationwide on <a href="direct%20broadcast%20satellite">satellite</a> via <a href="DirecTV">DirecTV</a>.
History.
The channel launched on March 4, 1988 as Sunshine Network, originally serving as an affiliate of <a href="Prime%20Sports">Prime Network</a>. The network was formed as a joint-venture of 11 cable companies and <a href="Home%20Sports%20Entertainment">Home Sports Entertainment</a>. Later that year, Sunshine would obtain rights to broadcast the <a href="Orlando%20Magic">Orlando Magic</a> in their inaugural <a href="1989-90%20Orlando%20Magic%20season">season</a>. In 1992, the network would also secure right to another new team, the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Lightning">Tampa Bay Lightning</a>. In its early years, the network also aired some <a href="Public%20affairs%20program">public affairs</a> programming in addition to sports.
Because Florida did not have a <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> team at the time, the network featured games from multiple teams including <a href="Texas%20Rangers%20%28baseball%29">Rangers</a>, <a href="Houston%20Astros">Astros</a>, <a href="Detroit%20Tigers">Tigers</a>, <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Orioles</a>, and <a href="Minnesota%20Twins">Twins</a>, along with college sports from <a href="University%20of%20Central%20Florida">UCF</a>, <a href="Florida%20State">Florida State</a>, <a href="Stetson%20University">Stetson</a> and <a href="Jacksonville%20University">Jacksonville</a> Universities. In 1993, Sunshine gained rights to the <a href="Miami%20Marlins">Florida Marlins</a> <a href="expansion%20team">expansion team</a>. In 1997, half of the 70 game schedule was moved to rival <a href="SportsChannel%20Florida">SportsChannel Florida</a> (which at the time was owned by Marlins' owner <a href="Wayne%20Huizenga">Wayne Huizenga</a>). The following season, the entire schedule was moved to SportsChannel.
In 1996, <a href="News%20Corporation">News Corporation</a>, which formed a <a href="Fox%20Sports%20%28United%20States%29">sports division</a> for the <a href="Fox%20Broadcasting%20Company">Fox Broadcasting Company</a> in 1994 with the acquisition of the television rights to the <a href="National%20Football%20Conference">National Football Conference</a> of the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a>, entered into a <a href="joint%20venture">joint venture</a> with <a href="Tele-Communications%20Inc.">TCI</a> spinoff <a href="Liberty%20Media">Liberty Media</a> and rebranded that company's Prime Network affiliates under the "Fox Sports Net" banner. Sunshine Network was the only <a href="Fox%20Sports%20Networks">Fox Sports Net</a> owned-and-operated charter outlet that did not rebrand under that name when it and the other Prime outlets relaunched as Fox Sports Net on November 1, 1996. Liberty Media (which at this point owned 49% of the network) proposed Fox Sports Sunshine as a new name for the network, but ultimately the rest of the owners did not approve it. In early 2000, Fox Sports Net programming moved from Sunshine to the newly rebranded <a href="Bally%20Sports%20Florida">Fox Sports Net Florida</a>.
Sunshine Network changed its name to Sun Sports on January 18, 2005, in order to reflect its sports-focused programming. Sun Sports and Fox Sports Florida were <a href="Corporate%20spin-off">spun off</a> with the rest of the Fox Sports Networks and most of News Corporation's other U.S. entertainment properties into <a href="21st%20Century%20Fox">21st Century Fox</a> in July 2013. On October 4, 2015, Sun Sports changed its name to Fox Sports Sun.
On December 14, 2017, as part of a merger between both companies, <a href="The%20Walt%20Disney%20Company">The Walt Disney Company</a> announced plans to acquire all 22 regional Fox Sports Networks from <a href="21st%20Century%20Fox">21st Century Fox</a>, including Fox Sports Sun and sister network Fox Sports Florida. However, on June 27, 2018, the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20Justice">Justice Department</a> ordered their divestment under antitrust grounds, citing Disney's ownership of <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a>. On May 3, 2019, <a href="Sinclair%20Broadcast%20Group">Sinclair Broadcast Group</a> and <a href="Entertainment%20Studios">Entertainment Studios</a> (through their joint venture, <a href="Diamond%20Sports%20Group">Diamond Holdings</a>) bought <a href="Fox%20Sports%20Networks">Fox Sports Networks</a> from <a href="The%20Walt%20Disney%20Company">The Walt Disney Company</a> for $10.6 billion. The deal closed on August 22, 2019. On November 17, 2020, Sinclair announced an agreement with casino operator <a href="Bally%27s%20Corporation">Bally's Corporation</a> to serve as a new <a href="naming%20rights">naming rights</a> partner for the FSN channels. Sinclair announced the new Bally Sports branding for the channels on January 27, 2021. On March 31, 2021, coinciding with the <a href="2021%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20season">2021 Major League Baseball season</a>, Fox Sports Sun and sister network Fox Sports Florida were rebranded as Bally Sports Sun and Bally Sports Florida, resulting in 18 other Regional Sports Networks renamed Bally Sports in their respective regions. The first live sports event on Bally Sports Sun was at 7 PM featuring the Miami Heat at the <a href="Indiana%20Pacers">Indiana Pacers</a>. The game was preceded with the "Heat Live" pregame show.
Programming.
Bally Sports Sun holds the regional cable television rights to the <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">NBA</a>'s <a href="Miami%20Heat">Miami Heat</a>, the <a href="National%20Hockey%20League">NHL</a>'s <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Lightning">Tampa Bay Lightning</a>, and the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Rays">Tampa Bay Rays</a> of <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>. In addition, Bally Sports Sun offers <a href="college%20basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="college%20football">football</a>, baseball and other sanctioned sporting events from <a href="Florida%20State%20University">Florida State University</a>. Bally Sports Sun has long maintained a partnership with the University of Florida and Florida State, producing all regular season football game telecasts for both universities and airing them statewide on the channel on a day-behind basis. However, with the launch of the SEC Network, University of Florida programming now consists of GatorZone and coaches shows.
Bally Sports Sun maintains separate feeds for individual regions of the state, with feeds for Miami (covering <a href="South%20Florida">South Florida</a>), Tampa (covering western Florida) and Orlando (covering northern and <a href="central%20Florida">central Florida</a>). The separation of broadcast zones for the channel is mostly due to the defined broadcast territories set by the National Basketball Association for the Orlando Magic and Miami Heat, and by the National Hockey League for the Tampa Bay Lightning. Programming seen in each broadcasting zone is common in most areas, and includes a mix of programs supplied by Bally Sports and some original programming exclusive to Bally Sports Sun and Bally Sports Florida.
Bally Sports Sun is also home to outdoor programming, highlighted by extensive salt and fresh water fishing programs such as the Chevy Florida Insider Fishing Report and Sportsman's Adventures.
Programming rights with Bally Sports Florida.
Bally Sports Sun shares the broadcast rights to the aforementioned professional sports teams with Bally Sports Florida. As the two regional networks are commonly owned, events from any team/conference in which Bally Sports Sun and Bally Sports Florida broadcasts are able to air on either channel depending on the start time of each team's respective games (particularly with the Marlins and Rays, since both teams routinely play at concurring start times).
The two channels do not focus on one region of Florida (although it was long rumored since the two came under common ownership that Bally Sports Sun would carry only teams from the Orlando and <a href="Tampa%20Bay">Tampa Bay</a> areas, while Bally Sports Florida would carry Miami-area teams), but simply distribute games in accordance with each team's territorial rights, with both cable channels maintaining joint exclusivity over regional broadcasts of Lightning, Heat, Marlins, Rays and the Magic, while Bally Sports Florida maintains exclusive regional rights to NHL games involving the Miami-based <a href="Florida%20Panthers">Florida Panthers</a>.
In 2010, the <a href="Miami%20Marlins">Miami Marlins</a> moved all of their Major League Baseball games to Bally Sports Florida, while the Tampa Bay Rays began carrying all their games on Bally Sports Sun. Prior to 2009, some Rays games were available on <a href="terrestrial%20television">broadcast television</a> stations in the state via a network made up of the state's <a href="Ion%20Television">Ion Television</a> stations.
